title: Crits. Is it a problem?
body:
Just something i've been thinking about for a while. Crits has a chance to allow you to deal double the amount of damage which is based on your %. With 10% crit chance it can win you a trade or even a duel against someone with superior items. It's essentially a system not based around skill but around luck. 

One of the solutions I hear about recently is to rework the crits system into something like what Ashe has but if that happens then what would make Ashe unique besides a walking ult? Would Ashe's crit system even be usefully applicable in a balance perspective? 

What are your guy's thoughts? Is the crit system fine the way it is or does it have room for improvements?

replies.body:
Make it so crit chance isn't a chance, but an order time system, where if you have 10%, every 10 autos will crit and if you have 50% every 2 autos will crit.

This adds both skill and counterplay by giving the champion with crits something to tract and account for.
For example, an ADC could invest in crit early in laning phase and time their autos for harass in lane. it would also make it far less stupid when last hitting to accidentally miss CS because you got a crit and screwed up the timing.

Meanwhile, the enemy now has to take into account how many autos the enemy has done and now has to take into account that they can get hot with a crit auto if they aren't careful, or when being chased, they know that X auto will crit and they should avoid it. Essentially it creates windows of power and vulnerability for both parties.

Seriously, it isn't rocket science. 
Why Riot hasn't implemented this, i can only chalk up to crits being intentionally flawed to "soft nerf" them without making it legitimately balanced.

>Why Riot hasn't implemented this

Because while it may solve the problem of random crits, it introduces a much more serve problem. It gives every single autoattacking champion a new mechanic to play around that takes some priority over their actual kit. It would be a pretty homogenizing effect if everyone who builds crit started playing around a pokey stack-building mechanic. They don't want every champion who builds crit as a steroid to have a stack counting minigame. They've put that mechanic on certain champions like Caitlyn, and they aren't looking to make it something that absolutely everyone has.

If I want a stack counting minigame, I'll play Caitlyn. I don't want to have to do it no matter which ADC I'm playing. That sounds extremely boring.

It´s a rather big problem, as it takes away a lot of skill-dependance from the game and replaces it with luck.
RNG really should have no place in a competitive game, crits do add a lot of frustration to either players that get critted by low-chance opponents - or even crit users that just donßt crit despite running a 55%+chance and losing a fight over it. And they don´t add anything meaningfull to make up for the frustration.

\+ it really would be easy to just get rid of the rng without impacting the balance too heavily

DOTA 2 has abilites completley built around chance which changes every time you use it. There are abilities and items that make champions have a chance to miss attacks. Is this chance a little lucky or part of the regular gameplay? For example, twisted fate's passive is supposed to be for how much gold you earn for a  unit kill but Riot said they try to keep the balance to 3-4 gold a kill so when you get 6 gold the next minion will give 2 gold. Maybe critical strikes should be like this, the less crits you hit the more chance you have of hitting the next one or the other way around.

>Maybe critical strikes should be like this, the less crits you hit the more chance you have of hitting the next one or the other way around.

That is roughly how they work. The game works on a pRNG system. If you have a 50% chance to crit, then your first attack after critting will actually have less than a 50% chance to crit, and it increases each time you attack until you crit so that you'll still get a crit 50% of the time on average.

I heavily dislike the randomness of crit, and the mechanic itself has no real gameplay despite being an integral part of a whole class's power expression. However, one good thing about it is its explosive power: it gives an otherwise heavily DPS-dependent class access to bursts of power which allows them to feel stronger. A lot of proposed crit reworks advocated turning crit into a permanent percent autoattack damage multiplier (i.e. 1% crit means your basic attacks deal 1% more damage), but I'm not too big a fan of that either, since it removes the mechanic's explosive power and still doesn't add any gameplay.

A system I'd like to try out for crits, though, would be to turn it into a kind of three-strike mechanic akin to the one on Gypsylord's champions (e.g. {{champion:245}}'s innate, {{champion:150}}'s Hyper effect in mini-form, {{champion:254}}'s W) as well as {{champion:67}}'s Silver Bolts, where attacking an enemy three times in a row would "crit", though without dealing any bonus damage initially, and you could then modify those crits with innate effects (like the aforementioned mechanics) or bonus damage from items. The benefit to this is that it would keep crit as a DPS-focused mechanic, but would also keep its explosive power. It would also add a lot more gameplay and predictability to the mechanic on both ends (the player and their opponent), and could also have tons of potential for expansion: you could include all champions' crit animations for critical strikes, you could turn the aforementioned effects into crit modifiers (e.g. Vayne would deal true max health-based damage on every critical strike), and you could even get into crazy itemization expansions that could add crit modifiers of their own, and even apply to non-AD champions (you could have stuff like AP crit, tank crit or even support crit, none of which would make sense in the current framework). It would also allow a proper overhaul of current crit itemization, which is mostly pretty dry and uninteresting ({{item:3031}} doesn't really enhance gameplay in any way besides contributing a chunk of extra damage, and yet is still _the_ core marksman item).

Crit is also ridiculously gold efficient. Getting 75% crit is essentially increasing your damage by 75% Then getting IE increases that number to 117.5%.
